content.raw:
Can you reraise the information in the ImportError?  I'd specifically like to see the original traceback, if possible.

The way this is written right now will make it difficult to see where the ImportError actually happened if the error was unrelated to setup.py not being run correctly.  That might happen if I make a mistake during development, for example.

content.raw: I'm open to just catching the first import failure if that seems more targetted, but I think having an error with a helpful message raised to the user is a good idea in general.  We're used to seeing the error and know how to fix it, but the average joe user doesn't know what this means.

content.raw: I guess I'm just -1 on pushing the error deeper into the stack. We should emphasize that people shouldn't use the same directory for 2.x and 3.0. That makes the error traceback much simpler to just figure out.

pullrequest.title: Adding error message when trying to run yt without having run setup.py for this version

content.raw:
You think people should have separate installs for the different versions of yt that are both found in the same repository?  I think I'm -1 on that.  I thought the whole point of merging everything into the same repo (yt 2.x and yt 3.0) was to enable the code to be more consolidated, and potentially easier to swap between the two.

I'm only pushing the error 1 deeper into the stack, and I'm just including a yt specific exception with a helpful error message.  I didn't think this would be that controversial.

I guess that does fix the issue of not knowing which has not had "setup.py" run on it, but it seems like just having a single one is probably simpler for most users. Hmm...

So are people just totally against having this error message?  I'm just trying to make things more intuitive and helpful for everyone.

pullrequest.title: Adding error message when trying to run yt without having run setup.py for this version

content.raw:
For what it's worth, I only have one repo, and i manage switching back and forth by doing `hg up yt-3.0` or `hg up yt`, and then `setup.py develop`.  I don't normally forget the `setup.py` step but I do see why that might be confusing to someone who is not used to dealing with python packages.

In general I more or less agree with Sam and Matt that it's best to not think too much for a user and just let the error propagate as it normally would.  This allows a more experienced user to diagnose the issue and allows us to figure out what went wrong more easily if they contact the mailing list.  Another thing to think about is that `yt update` already manages this workflow in a more user-friendly manner.

One other issue is that this sort of error indirection can actually make it *more* difficult to debug stuff, particularly if you are accidentally catching errors unrelated to not running `setup.py`.  I alluded to this below, but after further reflection I don't think it's even worth implementing my suggestion - best to not catch the error at all.

Really, this is an education/documentation problem.  We need to make sure that the process of updating the code is clearly stated and that includes executing the setup script.
content.html:
For what it's worth, I only have one repo, and i manage switching back and forth by doing hg up yt-3.0 or hg up yt, and then setup.py develop. I don't normally forget the setup.py step but I do see why that might be confusing to someone who is not used to dealing with python packages.

In general I more or less agree with Sam and Matt that it's best to not think too much for a user and just let the error propagate as it normally would. This allows a more experienced user to diagnose the issue and allows us to figure out what went wrong more easily if they contact the mailing list. Another thing to think about is that yt update already manages this workflow in a more user-friendly manner.

One other issue is that this sort of error indirection can actually make it more difficult to debug stuff, particularly if you are accidentally catching errors unrelated to not running setup.py. I alluded to this below, but after further reflection I don't think it's even worth implementing my suggestion - best to not catch the error at all.

Really, this is an education/documentation problem. We need to make sure that the process of updating the code is clearly stated and that includes executing the setup script.

pullrequest.title: Adding error message when trying to run yt without having run setup.py for this version

content.raw:
I think that very simple solution would be to:

1. make `python setup.py develop` spit hidden file into *yt* directory, that would store current `__version__`
1. in `yt/__init__.py`, **if** that file exists, compare current `__version__` with the file contents and act accordingly

*UPDATE*: In principle we could store additional data there too, like revision used for build/develop etc. That would come handy in bug reports.
content.html:
I think that very simple solution would be to:

  1. make python setup.py develop spit hidden file into yt directory, that would store current __version__
  2. in yt/__init__.py, if that file exists, compare current __version__ with the file contents and act accordingly

UPDATE: In principle we could store additional data there too, like revision used for build/develop etc. That would come handy in bug reports.

If there is consensus, I'd be happy to code it up.
content.html: Interesting idea, Kacper. This would work, and the check in init.py would occur prior to any failed imports, so it would alleviate the problems others have alluded to above. Matt Turk Sam Skillman and Nathan Goldbaum what do you guys think of this idea? If there is consensus, I'd be happy to code it up.

pullrequest.title: Adding error message when trying to run yt without having run setup.py for this version

description:
I know a common mistake I make (and I assume there are others who do this too) is to switch versions of yt with an "hg up yt-3.0" or "hg up yt", and then forgetting to run "python setup.py develop" prior to trying to use yt.  Inevitably, this yields an error, which is somewhat opaque and may be non-intuitive for new users.

So I added a new import exception which returns a helpful message to the user when they are unable to import the default packages (when trying to "import yt" in a python session, or running yt from the command line).  The helpful message tells the user how to run setup.py to fix the problem.

I *think* this is the main reason this exception would be raised, but if I'm being too general here, please let me know how to fix it.
